photos.people: John Willis, Betty Willis, Dorothy Willis, Judy Willis
photos.description: Group portrait. Used in birth announcement of Mary Ellen Willis: May 29, 1947.
photos.notes: Image from card shown it item 0152.

photos.people: John Willis, Betty Willis, Dorothy Willis, Judy Willis
photos.description: Birth announcement of Mary Ellen Willis: May 29, 1947.
A post card photo looking south from the parking lot above the Lodge.  Floats, and boats on buoys.

This fellow clearly had a good day fishing, which tells me it was late 30's into the 40's.  If memory serves me correctly the limit in those heydays of salmon was 6.  Now its 1 if you are lucky enough to catch one.
Nice photo of Bath house on left, Cabin 3 in center, and cabin 4 on the right.  Judging from the cars this is late 30's - pre World War II.  (Ken)
TBD
Friends and family at one of Ken's early August birthdays, always held on the beach.
The Doe Bay Community Dock looking at Cypress Island across Rosario Straits.  (Ken)
Cleaning the mornings catch on the beach.  Will have to blow this up to try and identify people.  Looks like Karl Atwood cleaning fish on the left.

Carroll Culver hand excavating for the garage ,woodshed, and cooler room.  The wooden box on the left was on small rails that allowed the dirt to be dumped onto the beach where winter storms would wash it away. (see separate photo).  (Ken)

The hand dug excavation for the garage, woodshed, and food storage cooler which sat immediately to the south of the main lodge. An exellent photo showing the cart and rail system that moved the dirt to the beach for winter storms to wash away. (Ken)
TBD

The biggest airplane to ever land at Pt. Lawrence. My father called it a "flying boat". A large amphibian plane resting on the beach in front of the Lodge. I cannot recall if this was privately owned or had been charted to bring a guest. I do know as a small boy I was duly impressed.  (Ken)
Carroll Culver with one of the Holen brothers (they were identical twins - Elmer and Helmer).   Helmer had a cool mustache and was my favorite.(Ken)

The marine rail was the second iteration of launching and retreiving the rental boats from the boathouse below the Lodge.  The first device is shown in earlier photos and used an overhead beam which extended out from the middle of the lodge (under the right hand end of the porch above.  I have reason to believe that neither would survive intact through most big winter windstorms since large waves pounded against that wooden bulkhead and often had floating logs that would slam against it.  Carroll probably had to disassemble these in the fall before the big storms.

The biggest airplane to ever land at Pt. Lawrence. My father called it a "flying boat". A large amphibian plane resting on the beach in front of the Lodge. I cannot recall if this was privately owned or had been charted to bring a guest. I do know as a small boy I was duly impressed.  (Ken)

Carroll Culver constructing the main Lodge platform.  The platform was built on cedar logs, using locally milled cedar boards.  It allowed rental boats stored in the boathouse to be rolled to the "lower platform" by the smokehouse for launch and retrieval, and was the foundation for the overhead ramp leading to the office,store, and porch from the parking lot and road above.  (Ken)

The biggest airplane to ever land at Pt. Lawrence. My father called it a "flying boat". A large amphibian plane resting on the beach in front of the Lodge. I cannot recall if this was privately owned or had been charted to bring a guest. I do know as a small boy I was duly impressed.  (Ken)

Smokehouse clearly visible on the left, then the marine railway to launch the rental boats stored in the boat house and rolled out/in on a little 2 wheel dolly (still in the boat house). The fish weighing scales can be seen just over the right shoulder of the person siting on the hand rail. This photo is prior to the construction of the concrete bulkheads that replaced the vertical cedar logs that fronted the main lodge building. Smoke coming from a beach fire and also from the bathhouse (upper left) so someone was planning a shower.  You can see the porch roof support detail of Cabin #1 which has now been replicated in the current upper cabin owned by Ken Culver's Family.  (Ken)

Am dating this photo based on the fact that there was no overhead walkway, the platform had not been built, and the marine railway was just outside the boathouse door. Also no garage/woodshed/storeroom yet. Note the huge fir tree towering over the lodge on the side of the hill above the parking lot. Sometime after this photo, when I was a small boy, a logger climbed that tree using spiked climbers and topped about 50 feet using a hand saw. I will never forget the image of the logger hanging on for dear life as the remainder of the tree swung wildly back and forth in a huge arc after the top of the tree came crashing down. The large box on the beach at the far left looks like part of the floating bait box used by Cap. Bell.  (Ken)
